children.text: During this holiday break,
The Lever
is resurfacing some of our best, most important reporting of 2022. We will return to our normal publishing schedule in the new year.

children.html: In the meantime, consider being part of holding the powerful accountable in 2023. You can click here for a major year-end discount to become a supporting subscriber. Your donation will directly fund The Lever‚Äôs independent investigative journalism that exposes and holds accountable those in power. And remember, when you subscribe, you get all sorts of exclusive stuff, including access to our live events, our premium podcasts, our Citizens Guide To Holding The Powerful Accountable, and more.

Your paid subscription has funded The Lever‚Äôs independent investigative journalism this year. We can‚Äôt thank you enough. If you wish to help us go even further in 2023, consider upgrading to a Lever Leader subscription, which comes with an annual special gift, a personal call-out in an upcoming post, a free gift subscription, access to an exclusive sneak peek at the organization‚Äôs future plans, and more.

Even if you don‚Äôt upgrade, we deeply thank you for your support ‚Äî we couldn‚Äôt do this work without you.

children.text: EDITOR‚ÄôS NOTE: Most corporate news outlets steer clear of scrutinizing efforts to privatize Medicare, the federal health insurance program for people 65 and older ‚Äî but we know better. In March,
The Lever
‚Äôs Matthew Cunningham-Cook revealed that President Joe Biden was forcing hundreds of thousands of seniors onto private health care plans
without their informed consent
. We then exposed how these private health plans are
funneling big profits
to a shadowy network of private equity firms and health care companies, while saddling patients with higher costs and shoddier care. We continued to cover the issue, reporting on how Biden
hiked payments
to private Medicare Advantage insurance plans, how Amazon
got in on the privatization action
, and how the
AARP is boosting

privatization for its own financial advantage. We‚Äôll continue to do so, since we know that the corporate takeover of health care for the nation‚Äôs most vulnerable is big, important news. Read our first story in the series below.
Seniors‚Äô Medicare Benefits Are Being Privatized Without Consent
By
Matthew Cunningham-Cook

A new Medicare privatization scheme developed under President Donald Trump and now being expanded under President Joe Biden is forcing hundreds of thousands of seniors onto new private Medicare plans without their consent.

The development represents a troubling new dimension in the fight by corporate interests to privatize Medicare, the federal health insurance program for people 65 or older. Medicare Advantage, which allows for-profit health insurers to offer privatized benefits through Medicare, already results in
unexpected costs
for routine procedures and
wrongful denials of care
. Private plans have cost Medicare an
astonishing $143 billion
since 2008
and
are now driving
some health insurers‚Äô record profits.

The new Direct Contracting Entity (DCE) program similarly adds a private-sector third party between patients and Medicare services. Medicare allows these intermediary companies to offer unique benefits, like gym membership coverage. But as for-profit operations
ranging from
private insurers to publicly traded companies to private equity firms, these intermediaries are incentivized to limit the care that patients receive, especially when they are very sick.

While Medicare Advantage patients choose to sign up for private insurance plans, patients are being enrolled in these DCE health care plans without their informed consent. As Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) noted in a January
op-ed

, ‚ÄúSeniors in traditional Medicare may be ‚Äòauto-aligned‚Äô to a DCE if any primary care physician they‚Äôve visited in the past two years is affiliated with that DCE. That means Medicare automatically searches two years of seniors‚Äô claims history without their full consent to find any visits with a participating DCE provider as the basis for enrollment.‚Äù

children.productDescription: Score a copy of our Citizens‚Äô Guide to Following the Money and Holding the Powerful Accountable, free with a paid subscription. The e-book gives you all the tools and tricks our reporting team uses to scrutinize power.
children.productButton: CLICK HERE TO GET YOUR COPY

children.text: Among those who unexpectedly found themselves caught up in one of these new DCE plans is Suzanne Gordon, a policy analyst based in Richmond, California. Gordon spent her entire professional career studying the U.S. health care system and advocating for Medicare for All. As a firm opponent of privatization in Medicare, she has never signed up for a for-profit Medicare Advantage plan.
That‚Äôs why she was so surprised when she got an email in January from her doctor at One Medical, a for-profit primary care practice on the West Coast
backed

by the private equity giant Carlyle Group. While the email message wasn‚Äôt particularly clear, she eventually realized that she was being enrolled without her informed consent in a new private DCE plan run by
Iora Health
, a primary care provider One Medical purchased last year.

‚ÄúI got the email, I clicked on it and began a signing process that didn‚Äôt tell me what I was signing,‚Äù said Gordon. ‚ÄúYou sign, you click in, and they tell you that they want you to sign up for a DCE with Iora Health. I wrote back to my doc and said I won‚Äôt do this‚Ä¶ I felt that a line had been crossed.‚Äù
Gordon, a health policy expert, was able to get out of the plan ‚Äî but others have not been so lucky. Rep. Pramila Jayapal‚Äôs (D-Wash.) office told
The Lever
that 350,000 seniors were in DCE plans as of January 2022 ‚Äî none of whom elected to sign up voluntarily.

This latest Medicare privatization scheme was started under the leadership of a Trump official who has since launched his own ‚Äúentrepreneurial firm focused on building and growing transformational health care companies,‚Äù with support from private equity firms. Now, the effort is quietly being expanded by the Biden administration through its new ACO REACH program, under the direction of two former Obama administration officials who have revolved between jobs in government and the corporate health care industry.
The development means that even more of the country‚Äôs most vulnerable will be at the mercy of corporate arbiters that they know little or nothing about.

‚ÄúSeniors and people with disabilities are, without their consent or full knowledge, being put into a program that has as its center the profit of the investment community rather than the health of Medicare members,‚Äù said Ed Weisbart, a physician who chairs the Missouri chapter of Physicians for a National Health Program (PNHP), a doctors organization that advocates for single-payer health care. ‚ÄúThe investment community has proven that they know how to work around the guardrails of any program that has been set up. They know how to do it.‚Äù
Privatizing Medicare
The DCE program was originally launched in
April 2019
by Trump‚Äôs Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), under the auspices of the CMS Innovation Center, known as CMMI.

CMMI was created under President Barack Obama‚Äôs signature health care law, the Affordable Care Act (ACA), to pilot new payment models in Medicare and Medicaid without going through the formal rulemaking process that requires public comment. As a result, the new DCE program, which assigns seniors to a privatized model without their consent, has never been subject to any public scrutiny whatsoever.
‚ÄúAll that DCEs do is privatize traditional Medicare,‚Äù said Diane Archer, the CEO of Just Care USA, which works to fight Medicare privatization.
Meanwhile, Adam Boehler, who Trump tapped to run CMS‚Äô Innovation Center, has since
formed
his own firm, Rubicon Founders. The firm‚Äôs
website

claims it will ‚Äúarchitect transformational companies and are deliberate in creating the foundation necessary to lead an industry,‚Äù but provides few details on how it will do so. Rubicon did not respond to a request for comment.
Boehler‚Äôs firm launched with the backing of longtime private equity executive
Annie Lamont
, who is married to Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont (D), as well as support from the health care-focused private equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe (WCAS). WCAS is
developing
a series of primary care centers for Medicare Advantage patients with the help of Humana, a private health insurer that has also
launched
a DCE program.
For Archer, the evidence is clear: ‚ÄúAdam Boehler‚Ä¶ launched this [DCE] program to enrich his friends in the private equity world.‚Äù

children.text: ‚ÄúWe Needed To Make Sure That CMS Continues This Journey‚Äù
Late last month, critics of DCEs say the Biden administration effectively
expanded
the DCE effort under a new name ‚Äî the ‚ÄúACO REACH‚Äù program.

The new program ‚Äî which stands for Accountable Care Organization (ACO) Realizing Equity, Access, and Community Health (REACH) Model ‚Äî allows hospital-led managed care organizations to access the new Medicare privatization scheme, too. ACO REACH similarly assigns patients with little informed consent to for-profit plans that benefit health care profiteers and creates incentives to deny care.

The DCE and ACO REACH programs are being spearheaded in part by CMMI head Liz Fowler, a former Obama administration official who helped write Obama‚Äôs signature health care act as the chief health counsel to former U.S. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus (D-Mont.). Earlier, she
helped write
the 2003 Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act,
legislation
that barred the government from negotiating lower prescription drug prices.

Fowler served as vice president of public policy for the health insurer Wellpoint, now part of Anthem, before moving to Baucus‚Äô office. She later became a health care aide in the Obama administration, before spending nearly seven years as a vice president for pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson.
Neither Anthem nor Johnson & Johnson are currently active in the DCE market. But considering other major insurers like Humana are pursuing DCE contracts, and that Anthem already
offers
Medicare Advantage plans, it is conceivable that these insurance giants could get into the business at some point in the future.
In a February 24 press call announcing ACO REACH, CMS Administrator Jonathan Blum said that the Biden administration had always been committed to continuing with the DCE program.

‚ÄúWe want to make sure that we see these programs as continuing to grow‚Ä¶ we have had many conversations with the public and with stakeholders that started with the new CMS team coming on board,‚Äù said Blum. ‚ÄúWe have felt from the start that we needed to make sure that CMS continues this journey.‚Äù
Blum served as the deputy administrator and later principal deputy administrator of CMS under Obama, before joining CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield as an executive vice president, according to
Legistorm

Fowler and Blum‚Äôs boss, CMS administrator Chiquita Brooks-Lasure, is a former health care partner at Manatt, Phelps & Phillips, a lobbying firm that worked to launch Medicare Advantage plans as recently as
Manatt, Phelps & Phillips also played an
integral
role in reducing fines for nursing home violations in California by as much as 99.9 percent in the middle of the COVID-19 pandemic.
The agency declined requests for comment.
A Dangerous New Stage Of Medicare Privatization

Kip Sullivan, an attorney who is active with Physicians for a National Healthcare Program, said that the DCE program relies on ensuring that elderly or disabled patients don‚Äôt have an informed choice about enrolling in the private health care plans.

‚ÄúSeniors have been swept into DCEs without their knowledge,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMany ‚Äî probably most ‚Äî beneficiaries are in traditional Medicare as opposed to Medicare Advantage because they did not want to be in a plan run by an insurer.‚Äù
Sullivan pointed out that the publicly traded DCEs, like Oak Street Health, brag in investor filings
that
between 13 and 30 percent of the money they get from Medicare goes into profits. By comparison, according to Sullivan, traditional Medicare plans have overhead of just 2 percent.
‚ÄúWhen Medicare passed in 1965, there was never an intention to enrich the insurance industry,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs exactly what‚Äôs happening.‚Äù

Weisbart, from the Missouri chapter of PNHP, is especially concerned that the Medicare and Medicaid agency ‚Äúdoes not need to get congressional consent, discussion or approval for any of these programs. They‚Äôre able to do it on their own.‚Äù
Under Trump, the agency even issued a
waiver

that exempts DCE programs from anti-kickback rules that normally prohibit doctors from entering their patients into such for-profit plans. As a result, doctors can be compensated for involuntarily entering their patients into DCE programs.
In recent months, advocates have been waging a full-court campaign against the DCE scheme. In January,
members of the House submitted a letter voicing similar concerns to Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra and CMS Administrator Brooks-Lasure.
What then, explains the Biden administration‚Äôs recent decision to expand the program?
As always in our campaign finance system, money could play a role. In 2020, the leadership of DCE contractor Clover Health donated
to the main super PAC for Senate Democrats, while the company‚Äôs financier Chamath Palihapitiya donated
to the same super PAC plus
to the Biden Victory Fund.
One Medical ‚Äî which employed Suzanne Gordon‚Äôs doctor and owns Iora Health, the company that tried to enroll her in a DCE -‚Äî is
backed
by
the Carlyle Group, a prodigious
donor
to both parties. Biden
enjoyed
Thanksgiving dinner last year at the $30 million Nantucket home of Carlyle co-founder David Rubenstein.
Bill Kadereit, the President of the National Retiree Legislative Network, said that the DCE program could usher in a dangerous new stage of Medicare privatization.

‚ÄúMedicare Advantage plans have failed,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPrivatization has failed. The cost of Medicare is doubling every ten years because of the health care sector campaign contributions. We‚Äôre seeing the disassembly and destruction of our precious public health system. Every place where the profiteers have stepped in costs have gone up and health outcomes have gone down.‚Äù
